dublinCore.description: An interactive simulation of the OODA Loop (Observe, Orient, Decide, Act) decision-making cycle developed by Colonel John Boyd. Demonstrates how speed through the decision cycle provides competitive advantage through visual comparison of two agents progressing at different rates.

learningObjectives: Define the four phases of the OODA loop: Observe, Orient, Decide, Act
Explain why decision-making speed provides competitive advantage in dynamic environments
Understand the iterative and cyclical nature of the OODA decision-making process
Apply OODA loop concepts to real-world scenarios in business, military, sports, and personal decision-making
Analyze how organizations can accelerate their decision cycles to gain competitive advantage
Evaluate the relative importance of each phase in the OODA loop for different contexts
prerequisites: Familiarity with competitive strategy concepts (helpful but not required)

accessibility.screenReaderScript: Interactive simulation of the OODA Loop showing two agents progressing through decision cycles at different speeds. Blue Agent and Red Agent move through four phases: Observe (blue), Orient (green), Decide (yellow), and Act (red). Controls allow adjusting each agent's speed to demonstrate competitive advantage of faster decision cycles.

controls.label: Agent 1 Speed
controls.description: Controls the speed at which the blue agent progresses through their OODA loop

controls.label: Agent 2 Speed
controls.description: Controls the speed at which the red agent progresses through their OODA loop

controls.label: Start/Pause
controls.description: Starts or pauses the simulation animation

controls.label: Reset
controls.description: Resets both agents to the start position and clears cycle counters

visualElements.description: Two circular OODA loops with rotating markers showing agent progress
Four-quadrant circular diagrams showing Observe, Orient, Decide, Act phases with distinct colors
Cycle counters showing completed decision loops for each agent

model.description: Simple angular progression model where agents move through a circular decision loop at adjustable speeds. Progress is measured in radians (0 to 2π), with one complete cycle representing one full OODA loop iteration.
equations: if (angle >= 2π) then cycles = cycles + 1; angle = angle mod 2π
assumptions: All four OODA phases take equal time within each agent's cycle
Speed remains constant unless adjusted by user
No external interruptions or delays affect the decision cycle
Both agents operate independently without interaction
limitations: Simplified model does not represent real-world complexity of decision-making
Does not model the quality of decisions, only the speed
Does not account for information quality or processing errors
Does not simulate the actual outcomes or effectiveness of decisions
Orient phase is not weighted more heavily despite Boyd's emphasis on its importance

scenarios.name: Equal Competition
scenarios.description: Both agents operate at the same speed, showing no competitive advantage

scenarios.name: Moderate Advantage
scenarios.description: Agent 1 has a moderate speed advantage over Agent 2

scenarios.name: Overwhelming Advantage
scenarios.description: Agent 1 operates much faster than Agent 2, demonstrating dominant position

scenarios.name: Slow and Deliberate
scenarios.description: Both agents operate at slower speeds for detailed observation

instructionalStrategies: Start with equal speeds to establish baseline understanding
Gradually introduce speed differences to show competitive advantage
Use predict-observe-explain pattern: have students predict outcomes before running
Facilitate discussion about real-world applications in business, military, sports
Connect to students' experiences with competitive situations
Challenge students to identify which OODA phase is most critical in different scenarios

assessmentQuestions.question: Who developed the OODA loop framework and in what context?
Explain why completing the OODA loop faster provides a competitive advantage.
Give a specific example of how a business could apply the OODA loop to gain competitive advantage.
Analyze which phase of the OODA loop (Observe, Orient, Decide, Act) is typically the bottleneck in organizational decision-making and why.
Evaluate whether speed through the OODA loop is always advantageous, or if there are situations where slower, more deliberate decision-making would be preferable.

extensions: Modify the simulation to weight the Orient phase more heavily based on Boyd's emphasis
Add obstacles or interruptions that randomly slow one or both agents
Create a version where agents can interfere with each other's decision cycles
Add a third agent to show multi-competitor dynamics
Implement different 'terrain' conditions that affect speeds in different phases
Add metrics for decision quality vs. decision speed trade-offs
Create scenario presets based on real historical examples (aerial combat, business competitions, etc.)
Add sound effects or audio cues when agents complete phases or cycles
